UK's most established female Muslim
rappers Sakina and Munira are used to
the spotlight challenging perceptions in
their performance there's so many
stigmas and stereotypes are attached to
Muslims and Muslim women we're supposed
to hate the West we're supposed to hate
you know homosexuals are supposed to

kind of stereotype is on us so when they
kind of see us and they realize that as
many things we're just human beings you
see the literally the stereotypes that
we have just being shadows born in
Bristol they told me at school friends
they shared a passion for music and a
desire to express their new faith we
converted to Islam three weeks before
the 7/7 bombings so we converted to
Islam next thing you know like Islam was
all over the news every day in a very
negative way and we decided like
straight away we felt like we wanted to
wear the headscarf so immediately your
your what you mean in society is
different you know before we were just
two afro-caribbean girls walking around
suddenly we're like a threat over an
enemy or we're you know suddenly were
like the enemy within
but mixing hip-hop and Islam hasn't
always had a positive reception how
